title: Fluoride prescriptions to children restricted by FDA - The Washington Post
---
<p>The agency concluded ingestible fluoride should be limited to children aged three years and older who are at high risk for tooth decay.</p>
<p>Most children should not receive prescription fluoride, Food and Drug Administration officials said Friday as they announced measures to restrict sales of the cavity-fighting drug.</p>
<p class="rw-outer-content"><span>Some content could not be imported from the original document.</span> <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2025/10/31/fda-fluoride-prescription-restrictions/">View content â†— </a></p><figure></figure>
<figure><img src="https://pl.primis.tech/live/liveView.php?"/></figure>
<figure><img src="https://pl.primis.tech/live/liveView.php?"/></figure>
<figure><img src="https://pl.primis.tech/live/liveView.php?"/></figure>
<p>The agency said children under 3 and older children not at high risk for tooth decay should avoid ingestible fluoride, which is often sold as tablets or drops. It sent<a href="https://www.fda.gov/media/189413/download"> letters</a> to manufacturers warning them not to market the products to such children.</p>
